sections.title: What's the best way to create a PDF?
sections.context:
What's the best way to create a PDF?
You can create PDFs from documents printed on paper, Microsoft Word documents, InDesign(r)
files, digital images, and more. Different types of sources have different tools available for PDF
conversion. In many applications, you can create PDFs by selecting the Adobe PDF printer in
the Print dialog box.
If a file is open in its authoring application (such as a spreadsheet that is open in Microsoft
Excel), you can convert it to PDF without opening Adobe Acrobat. Similarly, if Acrobat is
already open, you don't have to open the authoring application to convert a file to PDF.
Every PDF balances efficiency (small file size) and quality (such as resolution and color). If the
balance between the file size and the quality is critical to your task, you must use an
appropriate conversion method.
For example, you can drag files to the Acrobat icon to create PDFs. In this case, Acrobat
applies the most recently used conversion settings without providing access to those settings.
If you want more control over the process, you'll want to use another method.

sections.title: Balance PDF file size and quality
sections.context:
Balance PDF file size and quality
You can select various settings to ensure that your PDF has the best balance between file size,
resolution, conformity to specific standards, and other factors. The settings you select depend
on your goals for the PDF that you are creating. For example, a PDF intended for high-quality

sections.title: Acrobat Distiller
sections.context:
Acrobat Distiller
.
However, some settings are limited to specific contexts or file types. For example, PDFMaker
options can vary among the different types of

sections.title: Microsoft Office
sections.context:
Microsoft Office
applications.
For convenience, you can select one of the conversion presets available in Acrobat. You can
also create, define, save, and reuse custom presets that are uniquely suited to your purposes.
For scanned documents, you can choose from Autodetect Color Mode or several scanning
presets that are optimized for scanning documents and images in color or black and white.
You can modify these presets or use your own custom scanning settings.
There are various ways to create a PDF file using Acrobat. You can generate a PDF quickly
using the convert to PDF tool, menu commands, dragging-and-dropping files onto the
Acrobat application icon, or converting clipboard data.

sections.title: Drag-and-drop to create PDFs
sections.context:
Drag-and-drop to create PDFs
This method is best for small, simple files, such as small image files and plain text files, when
the balance between file size and output quality is not important. You can use this technique
with many other types of files, but you cannot adjust any conversion settings during the
process.
1.
Select the icons of one or more files in the Windows Explorer or macOS Finder.
2.
Drag the file icons onto the Acrobat application icon. Or (Windows only) drag the files
into the open Acrobat window.
If a message appears saying that the file could not be opened in Acrobat, then that
file type cannot be converted to PDF by the drag-and-drop method. Use one of the
other conversion methods for that file.
Note:
You can also convert PostScript and EPS files to PDF by dragging them onto
the Acrobat window or the Acrobat application icon.
3.
Save the PDF.

sections.title: Windows Explorer
sections.context:
Windows Explorer
and select
Convert

sections.title: Create a blank PDF
sections.context:
Create a blank PDF
You can create a blank PDF, rather than beginning with a file, a clipboard image, or scanning.
This process can be useful for creating a one-page PDF. For longer, more complex, or heavily
formatted documents, it's better to create the source document in an application that offers
more layout and formatting options, such as Adobe InDesign or

sections.title: Microsoft Word
sections.context:
Microsoft Word
.
Do any of the following:
*
In Acrobat, select
Create
from the global bar.
The Create a PDF tool opens. On the le rail, select

sections.title: Blank page
sections.context:
Blank page
, and then select
Create
.
*
Select the hamburger menu
>
Create
>

sections.title: Blank Page
sections.context:
Blank Page
(Windows),
or
File
>
Create
>

sections.context:
Blank Page
(macOS).
Acrobat creates a blank page PDF.

sections.title: Create multiple PDFs from multiple files
sections.context:
Create multiple PDFs from multiple files
You can create multiple PDFs from multiple native files, including files of different supported
formats, in one operation. This method is useful when you must convert a large number of files
to PDF.
Note
: When you use this method, Acrobat applies the most recently used conversion settings
without offering you access to those settings. If you want to adjust the conversion settings, do
so before using this method.
1.
In Acrobat, select
Create
from the global bar.
2.
The Create a PDF tool opens. On the le rail, select

sections.title: PDF files
sections.context:
PDF files
, and then select
Next
.
3.
Choose

sections.title: Add Folders
sections.context:
Add Folders
, and then select the files or folder.
4.
Select
OK
. The Output opons dialog box appears.
5.
In the

sections.title: Output Opons
sections.context:
Output Opons
dialog box, specify your target folder and filename
preferences, and then select
OK
.
Using PDFMaker within an authoring application is a simple, one-click procedure. It involves
clicking an Acrobat PDFMaker toolbar button or choosing a command on the Adobe PDF menu.

sections.title: About Acrobat PDFMaker
sections.context:
About Acrobat PDFMaker
PDFMaker is an Acrobat feature that operates within many business applications, such as
Microsoft Office applications, AutoCAD, and Lotus Notes. When you install Acrobat,
PDFMaker controls appear in the work area of the authoring application.
Note:
Some PDFMaker features are not available in certain versions of the authoring
applications. For a comparison chart, see
Compatible web browsers and PDFMaker
applications | Acrobat, Reader
.

sections.title: Using Create PDF cloud service for PDF
sections.context: Using Create PDF cloud service for PDF

sections.title: conversion
sections.context:
conversion
Acrobat provides an option to use Adobe Create PDF cloud service in addition to a local
conversion to convert Microsoft Word documents to PDFs. The created PDFs are high-quality
and provide exceptional visual fidelity. They are well-tagged for better accessibility. They also
include link recognition so that hyperlinks, internal document links, and tables of contents are
created as live links.

sections.title: Convert a file to PDF using PDFMaker
sections.context:
Convert a file to PDF using PDFMaker
In Windows, Acrobat installs both an Acrobat PDFMaker toolbar and an

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
menu in
many popular authoring applications. You can use either the toolbar buttons or the
Adobe
PDF
menu (the
Action
menu in Lotus Notes) to create PDFs, but the menu also provides access
to conversion settings. Although many of the conversion options are common to all authoring
applications, a few are application-specific.
For Microsoft Office applications such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, the options for creating
PDFs are available from the
Acrobat
ribbon.
Note:
If you don't see the PDF toolbar buttons in an application, you must show or activate the PDF
toolbar. For other troubleshooting issues, see Troubleshoot Acrobat PDFMaker Problems.

Select the

.
2.
Select Add-Ins on the left side of the dialog box.
3.
Do one of the following:
*
If PDFMOutlook or

sections.title: Acrobat PDFMaker Office COM Add-in
sections.context:
Acrobat PDFMaker Office COM Add-in
and select
OK
.
5.
Restart the Office application.

sections.title: View PDFMaker conversion settings
sections.context:
View PDFMaker conversion settings
PDFMaker conversion settings vary according to file types. For example, the options available
for PowerPoint files aren't the same as the options available for Outlook files. Once you've
selected conversion settings, those choices apply to all subsequent PDFs you create from that
file type. It's a good idea to review the settings occasionally.
1.
Open a PDFMaker-enabled application (such as Word or Excel).
2.
Do one of the following:
*
(Lotus Notes) Choose Actions >

sections.title: Change Adobe PDF Conversion Settings
sections.context:
Change Adobe PDF Conversion Settings
.
*
(Office 2010 applications) In the
Acrobat
or

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
ribbon,
click
Preferences
.
*
(All other applications) Choose

sections.title: Change Conversion Settings
sections.context:
Change Conversion Settings
.
3.
(Optional) To revert to the original default settings, click

sections.title: Restore Defaults
sections.context:
Restore Defaults
on
the
Settings
tab.

sections.title: Settings tab of the Adobe PDFMaker preferences
sections.context:
Settings tab of the Adobe PDFMaker preferences
The settings available for PDFMaker depend on the application in which you're using
PDFMaker.

sections.title: Conversion Settings
sections.context:
Conversion Settings
Specifies the standard by which the PDF will be optimized. When you choose an item in the
menu, a description of that preset appears immediately below it.

sections.title: View Adobe PDF Result
sections.context:
View Adobe PDF Result
Opens the converted document directly into Acrobat. (Exception: when you choose

sections.title: Adobe PDF And Email
sections.context:
Adobe PDF And Email
.)

sections.title: Prompt For Adobe PDF File Name
sections.context:
Prompt For Adobe PDF File Name
Lets you enter a custom filename for the resulting PDF. Deselect this option to save the file in
the same folder as the source file, using the same name but with a .pdf extension.

sections.title: Convert Document Information
sections.context:
Convert Document Information
Adds document information from the

sections.title: Properties
sections.context:
Properties
dialog box of the source file. This setting
overrides the printer preferences and settings in the

sections.title: Advanced
sections.context:
Advanced
panel of the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
Settings
dialog box.
Note:

sections.title: Advanced Settings
sections.context:
Advanced Settings
button opens the

sections.title: Adobe PDF Settings
sections.context:
Adobe PDF Settings
dialog box, which contains many
additional conversion options. These conversion settings apply to all Acrobat features that
create PDFs, such as Acrobat Distiller, PDFMaker, and the Acrobat application itself.
PDF/A Compliance
Creates the PDF so that it conforms to the selected ISO standard for long-term preservation of
electronic documents.

sections.title: Security tab of the Adobe PDFMaker preferences
sections.context:
Security tab of the Adobe PDFMaker preferences
The settings available for PDFMaker depend on the application in which you're using
PDFMaker.

sections.title: Require A Password To Open The Document
sections.context:
Require A Password To Open The Document
When selected, makes the

sections.title: Document Open Password
sections.context:
Document Open Password
option available, where you enter a
password that users must use to open the document.

sections.title: Restrict Editing And Printing Of The Document
sections.context:
Restrict Editing And Printing Of The Document
When selected, makes the other

sections.title: Permissions
sections.context:
Permissions
options available.

sections.title: Change Permissions Password
sections.context:
Change Permissions Password
Specifies a password you set that users must use in order to do any allowable printing or
editing.

sections.title: Printing Allowed
sections.context:
Printing Allowed
Specifies whether users who use the

sections.title: Permissions Password
sections.context:
Permissions Password
can print the document and at
what resolution.

sections.title: Changes Allowed
sections.context:
Changes Allowed
Specifies what changes users who use the

sections.title: Permissions Password
sections.context:
Permissions Password
can make.
Enable Copying Of Text, Images, And Other Contents
Prevents or allows users from copying from the PDF.

sections.title: Enable Text Access For Screen Reader Devices For The Visually Impaired
sections.context:
Enable Text Access For Screen Reader Devices For The Visually Impaired
Prevents or allows screen reader devices to read text. (Selected by default.)

sections.title: Enable Plaintext Metadata
sections.context:
Enable Plaintext Metadata
Specifies whether the search engine can read the document metadata. Available only when the
PDF-compatibility is set to Acrobat 6.0 (PDF 1.5) or later.

sections.title: Convert Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, and
sections.context: Convert Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, and

sections.title: Excel files to PDF
sections.context:
Excel files to PDF
When creating a PDF from Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, or Excel, you can set conversion
options for the current file. You can also select a range of content in the file to convert. The
conversion options that you can set in the following steps are some of the most commonly used
settings from the

sections.title: Acrobat PDFMaker
sections.context:
Acrobat PDFMaker
dialog box. Any changes you make to the conversion
options apply to the current conversion only.

sections.title: Convert Excel files to PDF
sections.context:
Convert Excel files to PDF
1.
Open a file in Excel.
2.
Optionally, select the cells to convert.
3.
From the
Acrobat
ribbon, select one of the
Create
options.
4.
In the

sections.title: Acrobat PDFMaker
sections.context:
Acrobat PDFMaker
dialog box, select a

sections.title: Conversion Range
sections.context:
Conversion Range
, then
choose

sections.title: Convert To PDF
sections.context:
Convert To PDF
.
5.
In the

sections.title: Save Adobe PDF File As
sections.context:
Save Adobe PDF File As
dialog box, specify a filename and location for the PDF.
6.
Optionally, select the
Options
button to change the conversion settings.
7.
Select
Save
to create the PDF.

sections.title: Convert Word and PowerPoint files to PDF
sections.context:
Convert Word and PowerPoint files to PDF
1.
Open a file in Word or PowerPoint.
2.
Optionally, select objects and text (Word) or slides (PowerPoint), as needed.
3.
(Office 2010) From the Acrobat ribbon, select Create PDF, Create And Attach to Email,
or Create And Send For Review.
4.
In the

sections.title: Save Adobe PDF File As
sections.context:
Save Adobe PDF File As
dialog box, specify a filename and location for the PDF.
5.
Optionally, click the
Options
button to change the conversion settings.
6.
Select a

sections.title: Slide Range
sections.context:
Slide Range
(PowerPoint). The Selection option is
available only if you have selected content in the file.
7.
Click
OK
, then click
Save
to create the PDF.

sections.title: Convert email messages to PDFs
sections.context:
Convert email messages to PDFs
You can use PDFMaker to convert one or more Microsoft Outlook or Lotus Notes email
messages or entire folders of messages to a merged PDF or

sections.title: PDF Portfolio
sections.context:
PDF Portfolio
. Within a
PDF

sections.title: Portfolio
sections.context:
Portfolio
, each email message appears as a separate PDF file.
The

sections.title: Acrobat PDFMaker Conversion Settings
sections.context:
Acrobat PDFMaker Conversion Settings
dialog box contains the option that determines
whether email messages are merged into one continuous PDF or assembled into a
PDF

sections.title: Portfolio
sections.context:
Portfolio
.
The controls that activate an email conversion to PDF appear in two places within the email
application: on the

sections.title: Acrobat PDFMaker
sections.context:
Acrobat PDFMaker
toolbar and on a menu. In Outlook, the menu is
called

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
and appears to the right of the Outlook Help menu. In Lotus Notes, PDF
commands appear under the Actions menu.
Note:
You can convert one currently open email message to PDF (not to a

sections.title: PDF Portfolio
sections.context:
PDF Portfolio
) by
choosing
File
>
Print
, and selecting

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
as the printer in the
Print
dialog box. The
PDFMaker conversion settings do not affect this process.

sections.title: Specify whether email messages become merged PDFs or PDF
sections.context: Specify whether email messages become merged PDFs or PDF

sections.title: Portfolios
sections.context:
Portfolios
1.
Do one of the following:
*
(Outlook) Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Change Conversion Settings
sections.context:
Change Conversion Settings
.
*
(Lotus Notes) Choose Actions >

sections.title: Change Adobe PDF Conversion Settings
sections.context:
Change Adobe PDF Conversion Settings
.
2.
Do one of the following:
*
To convert and merge email messages into a PDF as sequential pages of one
document, deselect

sections.title: Output Adobe PDF Portfolio When Creating A New PDF
sections.context:
Output Adobe PDF Portfolio When Creating A New PDF
File
.
*
To assemble converted email messages as components of a

sections.title: PDF Portfolio
sections.context:
PDF Portfolio
,
select

sections.title: Output Adobe PDF Portfolio When Creating A New PDF File
sections.context:
Output Adobe PDF Portfolio When Creating A New PDF File
.

sections.title: Convert an open email message to PDF (Outlook)
sections.context:
Convert an open email message to PDF (Outlook)
1.
Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Convert To Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Convert To Adobe PDF
.
Note:
You can also convert a different file to PDF from within an open Outlook email message if
the

sections.title: Attach As Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Attach As Adobe PDF
toolbar is shown. Clicking this button opens a series of dialog boxes

sections.title: Convert email messages to a new PDF
sections.context:
Convert email messages to a new PDF
1.
In Outlook or Lotus Notes, select the individual email messages.
2.
Do one of the following:
*
(Outlook) Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Create New PDF
sections.context:
Create New PDF
.
*
(Lotus Notes) Choose Actions >

sections.title: Convert Selected Messages To Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Convert Selected Messages To Adobe PDF
.
3.
In the

sections.title: Save Adobe PDF As
sections.context:
Save Adobe PDF As
dialog box, select a location, type a filename, and
click
Save
.

sections.title: Add email messages or folders to an existing PDF
sections.context:
Add email messages or folders to an existing PDF
1.
In Outlook or Lotus Notes, select the individual email messages or folders.
2.
Do one of the following:
*
(Outlook) Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Append To Existing PDF
sections.context:
Append To Existing PDF
,
or
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Append To Existing PDF
sections.context:
Append To Existing PDF
.
Note:
If you have already created one or more

sections.title: PDF Portfolios
sections.context:
PDF Portfolios
, you can choose from
recently created

sections.title: PDF Portfolios
sections.context:
PDF Portfolios
in addition to the

sections.title: Append To Existing PDF
sections.context:
Append To Existing PDF
option.
*
(Lotus Notes) Choose Actions >
Append Selected Message(s) To Existing

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
, or Actions >
Append Selected Folder(s) To Existing Adobe PDF
.
3.
Locate and select the PDF or

sections.title: PDF Portfolio
sections.context:
PDF Portfolio
to which you want to add the converted
emails, and click
Open
.
Note:
Do not type a new name for the PDF. If you do, a warning message appears
telling you that the PDF was not found. Click
OK
, and select a PDF without changing
its name.
4.
(Outlook only) If a message appears, alerting you that the existing PDF was created
using an earlier version of PDFMaker, do one of the following:
*
To create a

sections.title: PDF Portfolio
sections.context:
PDF Portfolio
from the original PDF archive, click
Yes
, and select a
name and location for the new archive. (The default name adds
_Portfolio
to
the original PDF filename.) When the conversion is complete and the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
dialog box closes, the new archive opens in Acrobat.
*
Click
No
to cancel the process.

sections.title: PDF Portfolios
sections.context:
PDF Portfolios
of email converted or migrated in Acrobat 8 or later, only new messages--
that is, messages that are not already part of the

sections.title: PDF Portfolio
sections.context:
PDF Portfolio
--are appended.

sections.title: Convert email folders to a new PDF
sections.context:
Convert email folders to a new PDF
PDFMaker can convert multiple folders to PDF in one procedure. It is not necessary to select the
folders at the beginning of the process because you can select them in a dialog box that
appears automatically.
1.
Do one of the following:
*
(Outlook) Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Create New PDF
sections.context:
Create New PDF
.
*
(Lotus Notes) Choose Actions >
Convert Selected Folder(s) To Adobe PDF
.
2.
In the
Convert Folder(s) To PDF
dialog box, select the folders. Then select or deselect
the

sections.title: Convert This Folder And All Sub Folders
sections.context:
Convert This Folder And All Sub Folders
option.
3.
In the

sections.title: Save Adobe PDF File As
sections.context:
Save Adobe PDF File As
, select a location and name for the

sections.title: PDF Portfolio
sections.context:
PDF Portfolio
.
When the conversion is complete, the new PDF opens in Acrobat.

sections.title: Set up automatic email archiving
sections.context:
Set up automatic email archiving
1.
Do one of the following:
*
(Outlook) Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Setup Automatic Archival
sections.context:
Setup Automatic Archival
.
*
(Lotus Notes) Choose Actions >

sections.title: Setup Automatic Archival
sections.context:
Setup Automatic Archival
.
2.
On the

sections.title: Automatic Archival
sections.context:
Automatic Archival
tab of the

sections.title: Acrobat PDFMaker
sections.context:
Acrobat PDFMaker
dialog box, select
Enable

sections.title: Automatic Archival
sections.context:
Automatic Archival
. Then select options for

sections.title: Frequency
sections.context:
Frequency
and the time of day at which
automatic archiving occurs.
3.
Select other options, according to your needs:

sections.title: Maintain Log Of Archival
sections.context:
Maintain Log Of Archival
Creates a record of each archiving session.

sections.title: Choose File
sections.context:
Choose File
Specifies the name and location of the archiving log.

sections.title: Embed Index For Faster Search
sections.context:
Embed Index For Faster Search
Creates an index that you can search to find specific words or characters instead of
having to search each individual document.
4.
Click
Add
, and select the email folders and subfolders. Then select or deselect
the

sections.title: Convert This Folder And All Sub Folders
sections.context:
Convert This Folder And All Sub Folders
option, as preferred, and click
OK
.
5.
In the

sections.title: Save PDF Archive File As
sections.context:
Save PDF Archive File As
dialog box, select a name and location for the
archived email PDF. Then click
Open
.
6.
Review the settings and the archive folder names listed in the
Acrobat

sections.title: PDFMaker
sections.context:
PDFMaker
dialog box, and do any of the following:
*
To add other email folders to the list, click
Add
and select the folder.
*
To remove folders from the list, select the folders and click
Delete
.
*
To change an archive file, select any folder name from the list, click
Change

sections.title: Archive File
sections.context:
Archive File
, and specify the name and location.
*
To start archiving email immediately, click

sections.title: Create PDFs from Word mail merges
sections.context:
Create PDFs from Word mail merges
Mail merges from Word generate documents like form letters--for one common example--
that are personalized with information like the names and addresses of the recipients. With
Acrobat PDFMaker, you can save steps by using a Word mail merge document and
corresponding data file to output mail merges directly to PDF. You can even set up PDFMaker to
attach those PDFs to email messages that are generated during the PDF-creation process.
Note:
For information on setting up files for the Word Mail Merge feature, see Microsoft Office Word
Help.
1.
In Microsoft Word, open the template that you have created as the basis of your mail
merge, or create the file using the Word Mail Merge toolbar and Mail Merge wizard,
as needed.
Note:
Do not complete the mail merge in Word. Instead, set up and preview the mail
merge as usual, so that you can verify that the merge will work correctly.
2.
Do one of the following:
*
Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Mail Merge
sections.context:
Mail Merge
.
*
Click the

sections.title: Mail Merge To Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Mail Merge To Adobe PDF
button on the Mail Merge toolbar (View >
Toolbars > Mail Merge).
3.
In the

sections.title: Acrobat PDFMaker - Mail Merge
sections.context:
Acrobat PDFMaker - Mail Merge
dialog box, select the options you want:
*
To specify which records in the data file will be imported into the merged
files, select
All
or
Current
, or enter a range of pages by typing in
the
From
and
To
boxes.
*
To name the PDF that will be created, type in the

sections.title: Specify PDF File Name
sections.context:
Specify PDF File Name
box.
Note:
The PDF will be named using this text plus a series of numbers. For example, if
you type

sections.title: Specify PDF File Name
sections.context:
Specify PDF File Name
box, the mail-merged PDFs
might appear as JulyLetter_0000123, JulyLetter_0000124, JulyLetter_0000125, and
so forth.
4.
For

sections.title: Automatically Send Adobe PDF Files By Emai
sections.context:
Automatically Send Adobe PDF Files By Emai
l, do one of the following:
*
To create and save merged PDFs for printing or sending later in email, leave
the option deselected, and click
OK
.
*
To create merged PDFs and attach each one to an email message to the
appropriate recipient, select this check box, and fill in the other Email options.

sections.title: Browse For Folder
sections.context:
Browse For Folder
dialog box appears, navigate to the location you want
to use and click
OK
.
Status indicators appear as PDFMaker generates the individual PDFs,
6.
If you selected

sections.title: Automatically Send Adobe PDF Files By Email
sections.context:
Automatically Send Adobe PDF Files By Email
, a dialog box appears
asking for your email profile. Enter the appropriate information and click
OK
.
When the job has finished, a message appears, telling you that the process was successful.

sections.title: Email options for PDF mail merges
sections.context:
Email options for PDF mail merges
To
Use the pop-up menu to select the field or column in the associated data file that contains the
email addresses in each individual's record.

sections.title: Subject Line
sections.context:
Subject Line
Type the text that you want to appear in the subject line of each message.
Message
Type to add or edit text that you want to appear in the body of the email messages.

sections.title: Convert Visio files to PDF (Acrobat Pro)
sections.context:
Convert Visio files to PDF (Acrobat Pro)
PDFs created from Visio files preserve page sizes and support layers, searchable text, custom
properties, links, bookmarks, and comments, depending on the conversion settings. To specify
the properties
*
(Visio 2010) From the ribbon choose
Acrobat
>
Preferences
When you convert your Visio file, only shapes and guides that are printable and visible in the
Visio drawing are converted and appear in the PDF. Shapes are converted regardless of their
protection or behavior. Shape custom properties can be converted to PDF object data.
When you convert the Visio file to a PDF, you can preserve all or just some layers, or you can
flatten all layers. If you flatten layers, the PDF will look like the original drawing, but won't
contain any layer information. When flattened, the contents of only visible and printable layers
will appear in the converted PDF.

sections.title: Convert Visio files
sections.context:
Convert Visio files
1.
If you want to change the PDFMaker conversion settings, do the following. (For
information about a setting, place the pointer over the setting to display a tool tip
below.)
*
(Visio 2010) Choose
Acrobat
>
Preferences
2.
If you want to convert each page in the Visio file to a bookmarked page in the PDF
file, choose

sections.title: Convert All Pages In Drawing
sections.context:
Convert All Pages In Drawing
. If this option is deselected,
only the current page is converted.
3.
Do one of the following:
*
(Visio 2010) Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Create PDF
sections.context:
Create PDF
.
*
(Visio 2010) Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Convert To Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Convert To Adobe PDF
.
*
(Visio 2010) Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Create and Attach To Email
sections.context:
Create and Attach To Email
. The PDF file
attaches to a new email message in your default email application.
*
(Visio 2010) Choose
Acrobat
>

sections.title: Create and Send For Review
sections.context:
Create and Send For Review
. The file converts
to an Adobe PDF file, and an email-based review process begins.
4.
If you want to include the custom properties of shapes, select that option.
5.
Click
Continue
.
6.
Select a layers option to retain or flatten layers in the resulting PDF, and
click
Continue
.
